required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress in Patients With Recurrent Pregnancy Loss
clinical_study.official_title: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress in Recurrent Pregnancy Loss

lead_sponsor.agency: Kanuni Sultan Suleyman Training and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Kanuni Sultan Suleyman Training and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: To evaluate endoplasmic reticulum stress in women with recurrent pregnancy loss and those who had healthy births in the same age group. The level of the unfolded protein X box binding protein 1 (XBP-1) is measured. It is aimed to show the effect of endoplasmic reticulum stress on recurrent pregnancy loss.

primary_outcome.measure: Show the effect of endoplasmic reticulum stress on recurrent pregnancy loss
primary_outcome.description: Serum value (pg / mL) of x box binding protein (XBP-1), which is one of the unfolded proteins indicating endoplasmic reticulum stress, is measured.

arm_group.description: Women between the ages of 18 and 45 who had a history of miscarriage under 3 weeks and above 22 weeks were included in this group.
Women between the ages of 18-45 who have not had a history of pregnancy loss and who have had at least one healthy birth and no known chronic diseases are included in this group.

intervention.description: Serum value (pg / mL) of x box binding protein (XBP-1), which is one of the unfolded proteins indicating endoplasmic reticulum stress, is measured.

study_pop.textblock: Loss of 3 or more pregnancy between the ages of 18 and 45 and women who have given at least 1 healthy birth in the same age group.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- with three or more miscarriages before 20 th week of gestation
- had no chronic or acute inflammatory disease
- used no steroids, anti-inflammatory, or antioxidant medications
Exclusion Criteria:
- had inflammatory diseases
- had systemic disease
- Anatomical abnormalities, infectious, endocrine, or genetic etiologies

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Kanuni Sultan Suleyman Training and Research Hospital
